standards.parent_tip: Ask your child 'who,' 'what,' 'where,' 'when,' and 'why' questions after reading together.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Mia woke up early on Saturday. She put on her boots and grabbed a basket. She walked to the garden and picked strawberries until the basket was full."

Where did Mia go?
questions.hint: Look at the third sentence — where did she walk to?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Leo's dog, Biscuit, loved to play fetch. Every afternoon, Leo would throw a tennis ball across the yard. Biscuit always brought it back, wagging his tail."

What did Leo throw?
questions.hint: Read the second sentence again — what did Leo throw across the yard?

questions.prompt:
Read: "On the first day of second grade, Emma felt nervous. She didn't know anyone in her new class. At lunch, a girl named Priya sat next to her and said, 'Want to share my crackers?'"

Why was Emma nervous?
questions.hint: Look at the second sentence — what made Emma feel nervous?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Grandpa and Tomas built a birdhouse together. They used wood, nails, and bright blue paint. They hung it on the oak tree in the backyard."

Who helped Tomas build the birdhouse?
questions.hint: Read the very first sentence — who was with Tomas?

questions.prompt:
Read: "It was raining hard, so the soccer game was canceled. Ava was disappointed. Her dad said, 'Let's play board games instead!' They played three rounds of her favorite game."

When was the soccer game canceled?
questions.hint: The very first sentence tells you why — and when!

standards.standard_description: Ask and answer who, what, where, when, why, how questions about key details in a text.

standards.parent_tip: After reading a story, ask your child 'What lesson did the characters learn?'

questions.prompt:
Read: "The ant worked all summer storing food. The grasshopper played and sang. When winter came, the ant had plenty to eat, but the grasshopper had nothing."

What is the lesson of this story?
questions.hint: Think about what the ant did differently — why was the ant okay in winter?

questions.prompt:
Read: "The tortoise and the hare had a race. The hare ran fast but stopped to nap. The tortoise kept going slowly and steadily. The tortoise crossed the finish line first."

What is the moral of this story?
choices: Slow and steady wins the race
questions.correct: Slow and steady wins the race
questions.hint: The tortoise never stopped. The hare did. Who won?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Rosa wanted the biggest piece of cake. She pushed ahead of everyone in line. Her friends were upset and didn't want to sit with her. Rosa wished she had waited her turn."

What is the lesson of this story?
questions.hint: What happened when Rosa pushed ahead? How did her friends feel?

questions.prompt:
Read: "A lion was caught in a hunter's net. A tiny mouse chewed through the ropes and set the lion free. The lion had once let the mouse go instead of eating it."

What is the message of this story?
choices: Even small friends can be a big help
questions.correct: Even small friends can be a big help
questions.hint: Who saved the lion? Was the mouse big or small?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Ben bragged that he was the best speller in class. During the spelling bee, he didn't study and missed an easy word. His friend Kai, who had practiced every night, won."

What is the central message?
questions.hint: Compare what Ben did and what Kai did to prepare.

standards.standard_description: Recount stories including fables and folktales and determine their central message, lesson, or moral.

standards.parent_tip: Ask your child how characters feel when something happens in a story and what they do about it.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Lily's sandcastle was knocked down by a big wave. She felt sad at first, but then she smiled and said, 'I'll build an even bigger one!'"

How did Lily respond to the challenge?
choices: She decided to build a bigger one
questions.correct: She decided to build a bigger one
questions.hint: What did Lily say after she smiled?

questions.prompt:
Read: "During the talent show, Jake forgot the words to his song. His face turned red. Then he took a deep breath and started over from the beginning."

How did Jake handle forgetting the words?
choices: He took a deep breath and started over
He asked the teacher for help
questions.correct: He took a deep breath and started over
questions.hint: What did Jake do after his face turned red?

questions.prompt:
Read: "When the power went out during the storm, Maya was scared. Her mom lit candles and they told funny stories. Soon Maya was laughing instead of being afraid."

How did Maya's feelings change?
choices: She stayed scared the whole time
She went from scared to laughing
questions.correct: She went from scared to laughing
questions.hint: How did Maya feel at the start? How did she feel at the end?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Sam's best friend moved to a different city. Sam was really sad. He asked his mom if they could write letters to each other. Now Sam and his friend are pen pals."

How did Sam respond when his friend moved away?
choices: He found a way to stay in touch
He was angry at his friend
questions.correct: He found a way to stay in touch
questions.hint: What idea did Sam have to solve the problem?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Nora's team lost the championship game. Some kids were upset, but Nora high-fived every player and said, 'We played our best. I'm proud of us.'"

What does Nora's response tell us about her?
questions.hint: Think about what Nora did and said after losing. Was she kind?

standards.standard_description: Describe how characters in a story respond to major events and challenges.

standards.parent_tip: Point out fun-sounding words when reading poems or songs together — ask why the author chose those words.

questions.prompt:
Read: "The rain came down, drip, drip, drop. It wouldn't quit, it wouldn't stop!"

What do the words 'drip, drip, drop' help you imagine?
questions.hint: Say 'drip, drip, drop' out loud — what does it sound like?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Swoosh went the broom across the floor. Swish, swish, swoosh — it swept some more!"

The words 'swoosh' and 'swish' help the reader —
choices: See the color of the broom
questions.hint: These words copy the sounds a broom makes!

questions.prompt:
Read: "Silly Sally sat on a seal, singing songs by the sea."

What makes this sentence fun to say?
choices: Many words start with the same sound
questions.correct: Many words start with the same sound
questions.hint: Look at the first letter of most words. What do you notice?

questions.prompt:
Read: "The leaves danced in the wind, twirling and spinning to the ground."

The word 'danced' makes the leaves seem —
questions.hint: When you dance, how do you move? Happy or sad?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Tick-tock, tick-tock, the clock on the wall. Tick-tock, tick-tock, it counts for us all."

Why does the author repeat 'tick-tock'?
choices: To copy the sound and rhythm of a clock
Because they forgot what to write
questions.correct: To copy the sound and rhythm of a clock
questions.hint: What sound does a clock make? Does the poem sound like that?

standards.standard_description: Describe how words and phrases supply rhythm and meaning in a story, poem, or song.

standards.parent_tip: After reading, ask 'How did the story start? What happened in the middle? How did it end?'

questions.prompt:
Read: "Once upon a time, a girl named Zara found a magic key. She used it to open a secret door in her attic. Behind the door was a land of talking animals. After many adventures, Zara returned home and locked the door."

Which part is the beginning of the story?
questions.hint: The beginning introduces who the story is about and what starts the adventure.

questions.prompt: In a story, what does the ending usually do?
choices: Wrap up the story and solve the problem
questions.correct: Wrap up the story and solve the problem
questions.hint: Think about what happens at the very end of most stories you've read.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Devin wanted to win the art contest. He painted every day after school. His painting of a sunset won first place!"

What is the problem at the beginning?
choices: Devin wanted to win the contest
questions.correct: Devin wanted to win the contest
questions.hint: The beginning tells you what the character wants or needs.

questions.prompt: Which part of a story introduces the characters and setting?
questions.hint: Where do you first meet the characters and learn where the story takes place?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Mia lost her puppy in the park. She looked everywhere. Finally, she heard barking behind the slide and found her puppy playing with another dog."

How does the ending conclude the action?
questions.hint: The ending solves the problem. What was Mia's problem?

standards.standard_description: Describe the overall structure of a story, including how the beginning introduces the story and the ending concludes the action.

standards.parent_tip: While reading, ask 'How does this character feel about what happened? Does the other character feel the same way?'

questions.prompt:
Read: "Ana thought the roller coaster was amazing and wanted to ride again. Her brother Carlos shook his head and said, 'No way, that was too scary!'"

How are Ana's and Carlos's feelings different?
choices: Ana loved it but Carlos was scared
Carlos loved it but Ana didn't
questions.correct: Ana loved it but Carlos was scared
questions.hint: What did Ana say? What did Carlos say? Are they the same?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Mom said, 'We should get a cat.' Dad said, 'I think a dog would be better.' Jayden said, 'Can we get both?'"

Who has a different point of view from Mom?
questions.hint: Mom wants a cat. Does Dad agree? Does Jayden agree exactly?

questions.prompt:
Read: "The farmer was happy when it rained because his crops needed water. The children were sad because they couldn't play outside."

Why do the farmer and the children feel differently about the rain?
choices: Rain helps the farmer's crops but stops the children's play
questions.correct: Rain helps the farmer's crops but stops the children's play
questions.hint: Think about why rain is good for the farmer and not fun for the kids.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Ella wanted to stay up late to watch a movie. Her mom said it was a school night and bedtime was 8 o'clock."

How is Ella's point of view different from her mom's?
choices: Ella wants to sleep but mom says no
Ella wants to stay up but mom wants her to go to bed
Mom wants to watch the movie too
questions.correct: Ella wants to stay up but mom wants her to go to bed
questions.hint: What does Ella want? What does Mom want? Are they the same?

questions.prompt:
Read: "In the story, the Big Bad Wolf said, 'I just wanted to borrow some sugar!' The Three Little Pigs said, 'He tried to blow our houses down!'"

How are the points of view different?
choices: The wolf says he was friendly but the pigs say he was dangerous
The wolf admits he was bad
questions.correct: The wolf says he was friendly but the pigs say he was dangerous
questions.hint: The wolf and the pigs tell different stories about the same event!

standards.standard_description: Acknowledge differences in the points of view of characters.

standards.parent_tip: When reading picture books, ask your child what the pictures tell us that the words don't.

questions.prompt: If a story says 'Tomas felt happy' and the picture shows him with a big smile and jumping, what do the words AND picture together tell you?
questions.hint: The words say happy. The picture shows a big smile AND jumping. That's MORE than just happy!

questions.prompt: A story's words say: 'It was a dark night.' The picture shows rain, lightning, and bent trees. What can you tell about the setting?
questions.hint: The words say dark. The picture adds rain, lightning, and bent trees. Put them together!

questions.prompt: Why are illustrations important in a story?
choices: They help you understand the characters and setting better
questions.correct: They help you understand the characters and setting better
questions.hint: Think about what you learn from looking at pictures in a story.

questions.prompt: A story says 'Maya walked into the room.' The picture shows Maya with wide eyes, an open mouth, and a room full of balloons and presents. What is probably happening?
choices: Maya is at a surprise party
questions.correct: Maya is at a surprise party
questions.hint: The words just say she walked in. But the PICTURE shows you what she found!

questions.prompt: The text says: 'The old man sat on the bench.' The picture shows him feeding pigeons with a gentle smile and a cane beside him. What do you learn from the picture that the words don't tell you?
choices: He's feeding pigeons and seems kind
questions.correct: He's feeding pigeons and seems kind
questions.hint: The words say he sat. What EXTRA information does the picture give?

standards.standard_description: Use information from illustrations and words to understand characters, setting, or plot.

standards.parent_tip: Read two versions of the same fairy tale and ask your child what's the same and what's different.

questions.prompt: Two versions of Cinderella both have a girl who goes to a ball. In one version, a fairy godmother helps her. In the other, magic fish help her. What is the SAME in both?
choices: A girl goes to a ball
questions.correct: A girl goes to a ball
questions.hint: Look for what happens in BOTH versions.

questions.prompt: When you compare two versions of the same story, you look for things that are —
questions.hint: Comparing means finding what's alike. Contrasting means finding what's different. You do both!

questions.prompt: In an American version of a folktale, the hero is a cowboy. In a Japanese version, the hero is a samurai. Both heroes save their village. What is DIFFERENT?
choices: The stories have a happy ending
questions.hint: What is the same? They both save a village. What changes between the two stories?

questions.prompt: Story A: A boy finds a golden egg laid by a goose. Story B: A girl finds a golden seed that grows into a money tree. How are these stories similar?
choices: Both characters find something magical and valuable
questions.correct: Both characters find something magical and valuable
questions.hint: A golden egg and a golden seed are both magical treasures. What's the bigger idea they share?

questions.prompt: Why might the same story be told differently in different cultures?
choices: People in other places don't like stories
Each culture adds its own setting, characters, and traditions
One version is right and the other is wrong
questions.correct: Each culture adds its own setting, characters, and traditions
questions.hint: Think about how a story told in Japan might have different details than one told in Mexico.

standards.standard_description: Compare and contrast two or more versions of the same story by different authors or from different cultures.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage your child to read a mix of stories and poems that challenge them just a little.

questions.prompt:
Read: "The wind howled through the trees as Sophie clutched her flashlight. She had promised to walk to the mailbox alone, and she wasn't going to break her promise. With each step, the shadows seemed to dance around her."

How is Sophie feeling?
questions.hint: She made a promise and kept going — that's brave. But the howling wind and shadows suggest she's also a little scared.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Jackson's painting looked nothing like the sunset he was trying to copy. He almost crumpled it up, but then his art teacher said, 'Art doesn't have to be perfect — it just has to be yours.'"

What did Jackson learn?
choices: Art should be a perfect copy
questions.hint: What did the teacher tell him? Does art have to be perfect?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Every day, the old lighthouse keeper climbed 137 steps to light the lamp. 'Ships depend on me,' he would say. Even in the worst storms, the light always shone."

What word BEST describes the lighthouse keeper?
questions.hint: He climbed 137 steps every day, even in bad storms. That takes commitment!

questions.prompt:
Read: "The squirrel buried an acorn in the fall. By spring, a tiny green sprout poked through the soil. Years later, it became the tallest oak in the forest."

What is this story mainly about?
choices: Small things can grow into something big
questions.correct: Small things can grow into something big
questions.hint: Think about the journey — from a tiny acorn to the tallest oak tree.

questions.prompt:
Read: "'I'll never make friends here,' whispered Amir on his first day at the new school. By the end of the week, he had joined the soccer team and made three new friends."

What happened that Amir did NOT expect?
choices: He went to a new school
questions.hint: What did Amir say at the beginning? Did that come true?

standards.standard_description: By end of year, read and comprehend literature in the grades 2-3 text complexity band proficiently.

standards.parent_tip: When reading nonfiction, pause and ask your child specific questions about who, what, where, when, and why.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Honeybees live in hives. A hive can have up to 60,000 bees! The queen bee lays all the eggs, and worker bees collect nectar from flowers."

What does the queen bee do?
questions.hint: Read the last sentence — what is the queen bee's special job?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Firefighters wear special gear to stay safe. Their helmets protect their heads. Their thick coats keep them safe from fire and heat."

Why do firefighters wear thick coats?
choices: To keep safe from fire and heat
questions.correct: To keep safe from fire and heat
questions.hint: The last sentence tells you exactly why!

questions.prompt:
Read: "George Washington Carver was a scientist who studied peanuts. He found over 300 uses for peanuts, including making soap, ink, and dye."

How many uses did Carver find for peanuts?
questions.hint: Look for the number in the second sentence.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Sea turtles travel thousands of miles through the ocean. They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs."

Where do sea turtles lay their eggs?
choices: On the beach where they were born
In a nest in a tree
questions.correct: On the beach where they were born
questions.hint: Read the second sentence — which beach do they go back to?

questions.prompt:
Read: "In 1969, astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the Moon for the first time. Millions of people watched on television."

When did astronauts first walk on the Moon?
questions.hint: The year is right at the beginning of the passage.

standards.standard_description: Ask and answer who, what, where, when, why, how questions about key details in a text.

standards.parent_tip: Ask your child what a passage is mostly about, then have them tell you what each paragraph focuses on.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Dogs make great pets. They are loyal and friendly. Many dogs can be trained to do tricks. Some dogs even help people who are blind."

What is the main topic?
questions.hint: The first sentence tells you the main idea. The rest gives examples!

questions.prompt:
Read: "Paragraph 1: Apples come in many colors — red, green, and yellow. Paragraph 2: Apples are good for you because they have vitamins and fiber."

What is Paragraph 2 mostly about?
questions.hint: Paragraph 2 talks about vitamins and fiber. That means it's about health!

questions.prompt: A passage has three paragraphs. One is about where penguins live. One is about what they eat. One is about how they raise their babies. What is the MAIN topic of the whole passage?
questions.hint: Each paragraph covers a different detail about the same animal.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Water can be a solid, a liquid, or a gas. Ice is solid water. Steam is water as a gas. The water you drink is a liquid."

What is the main topic?
questions.hint: The first sentence tells you the big idea — water has three forms.

questions.prompt: How can you find the main topic of a passage with many paragraphs?
choices: Think about what ALL the paragraphs are about together
questions.correct: Think about what ALL the paragraphs are about together
questions.hint: The main topic is the big idea that connects all the paragraphs.

standards.standard_description: Identify the main topic of a multiparagraph text as well as the focus of specific paragraphs.

standards.parent_tip: Help your child see how events or ideas connect — ask 'What happened because of that?'

questions.prompt:
Read: "First, the caterpillar eats lots of leaves. Then, it makes a chrysalis. Finally, it comes out as a butterfly."

What happens AFTER the caterpillar makes a chrysalis?
questions.hint: Follow the steps: eat → chrysalis → what comes last?

questions.prompt:
Read: "The sun heats the ocean water. The water evaporates into the air. Clouds form. Then rain falls back to the ground."

What causes clouds to form?
questions.hint: What happens right BEFORE clouds form?

questions.prompt:
Read: "In 1903, the Wright Brothers flew the first airplane. Their flight lasted only 12 seconds. Today, planes can fly across the whole world."

How are the events connected?
choices: The Wright Brothers' invention led to modern airplanes
The Wright Brothers flew across the world
questions.correct: The Wright Brothers' invention led to modern airplanes
questions.hint: The first event (1903 flight) started something big. What came from it?

questions.prompt:
Read: "To make a peanut butter sandwich: First, get two slices of bread. Next, spread peanut butter on one slice. Then, put the other slice on top."

What do you do right AFTER spreading peanut butter?
choices: Put the other slice on top
questions.correct: Put the other slice on top
questions.hint: Follow the steps in order — what comes right after spreading?

questions.prompt:
Read: "When bees visit flowers, pollen sticks to their legs. They carry the pollen to other flowers. This helps new plants grow."

How does pollen getting on bees connect to new plants growing?
choices: Bees carry pollen to other flowers, which helps plants grow
questions.correct: Bees carry pollen to other flowers, which helps plants grow
questions.hint: Follow the chain: pollen on legs → carried to flowers → what happens?

standards.standard_description: Describe the connection between a series of historical events, scientific ideas, or steps in technical procedures.

standards.parent_tip: When your child encounters a new word, help them use the rest of the sentence to figure out what it means.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Nocturnal animals are active at night. Owls, bats, and raccoons are nocturnal."

What does 'nocturnal' mean?
questions.hint: The sentence right after 'nocturnal' tells you — active at what time?

questions.prompt:
Read: "A habitat is the natural home of an animal or plant. A frog's habitat is near ponds and streams."

What is a 'habitat'?
questions.hint: The first sentence gives you the definition!

questions.prompt:
Read: "Mammals are warm-blooded animals that have fur or hair. Dogs, cats, and humans are all mammals."

Based on the text, what makes an animal a mammal?
choices: It is warm-blooded with fur or hair
questions.correct: It is warm-blooded with fur or hair
questions.hint: The first sentence describes exactly what a mammal is.

questions.prompt:
Read: "The ancient Egyptians built enormous pyramids. These huge stone structures still stand today."

What does 'enormous' mean in this sentence?
questions.hint: The next sentence calls them 'huge stone structures.' That's a clue!

questions.prompt:
Read: "Plants need nutrients from the soil to grow. Nutrients are like food for plants — they give plants energy and help them stay healthy."

What are 'nutrients'?
choices: Food-like substances that help plants grow
questions.correct: Food-like substances that help plants grow
questions.hint: The second sentence explains it — nutrients are like food for plants!

standards.standard_description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 2 topic or subject area.

standards.parent_tip: Point out bold words, headings, and captions in nonfiction books and explain how they help readers.

questions.prompt: You want to find the meaning of the word 'ecosystem' in a science book. Where should you look?
questions.hint: A glossary is like a mini-dictionary at the back of a book!

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of a heading in a nonfiction text?
choices: To tell you what that section is about
questions.correct: To tell you what that section is about
questions.hint: Headings are like little titles for each section.

questions.prompt: You want to know which page has information about dolphins. Which text feature should you use?
questions.hint: An index lists topics alphabetically with their page numbers!

questions.prompt: In a nonfiction book, some words are in bold print. Why?
choices: Because the author likes those words
To show important or new vocabulary words
To make the page look pretty
questions.correct: To show important or new vocabulary words
questions.hint: Bold words stand out because they're important for the reader to know!

questions.prompt: A small sentence under a photograph that explains what's in the picture is called a —
questions.hint: Think of the little labels under photos in books and magazines.

standards.standard_description: Know and use various text features to locate key facts or information efficiently.

standards.parent_tip: Ask your child 'Why did the author write this? To teach us something, to tell a story, or to convince us of something?'

questions.prompt:
Read: "Brush your teeth twice a day. Use toothpaste with fluoride. Visit the dentist every six months."

What is the author's purpose?
choices: To explain how to take care of your teeth
questions.correct: To explain how to take care of your teeth
questions.hint: The author is giving you instructions about dental health.

questions.prompt:
Read: "The blue whale is the largest animal ever to live on Earth. It can be over 100 feet long and weigh as much as 200 tons."

The author wrote this to —
choices: Convince you to visit the ocean
Tell a story about a whale
questions.hint: Is the author giving you facts or telling a story?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Everyone should recycle! When we recycle, we save trees and keep trash out of the ocean. Please recycle your cans, bottles, and paper."

The author's main purpose is to —
choices: Teach you how paper is made
questions.hint: Words like 'should' and 'please' are clues that the author wants you to DO something.

questions.prompt: A book that teaches you about different types of clouds was written to —
questions.hint: If a book teaches you facts, the purpose is to inform!

questions.prompt:
Read: "Butterflies have four stages in their life: egg, caterpillar, chrysalis, and butterfly. Each stage is an important part of their life cycle."

What question is the author trying to answer?
choices: What are the stages of a butterfly's life?
questions.correct: What are the stages of a butterfly's life?
questions.hint: The passage lists stages. What question does that answer?

standards.standard_description: Identify the main purpose of a text, including what the author wants to answer, explain, or describe.

standards.parent_tip: When you see diagrams or photos in a book, ask your child what new information the picture adds.

questions.prompt: A science book has a paragraph about the parts of a plant. Next to it is a diagram with labels pointing to the roots, stem, leaves, and flower. How does the diagram help?
choices: It makes the page look nice
It shows you exactly where each plant part is
questions.correct: It shows you exactly where each plant part is
questions.hint: The paragraph tells you ABOUT the parts. The diagram shows you WHERE they are.

questions.prompt: A text about weather says: 'A thermometer measures temperature.' Below it is a picture of a thermometer showing 32°F. What does the picture add?
choices: It shows what a thermometer looks like and how to read it
It replaces the need to read
questions.correct: It shows what a thermometer looks like and how to read it
questions.hint: The words explain what it does. The picture shows what it LOOKS like and a reading.

questions.prompt: Why would an author include a map in a book about animals around the world?
choices: To show where different animals live
questions.correct: To show where different animals live
questions.hint: Maps show locations. If the book is about animals around the world, what would a map show?

questions.prompt: A book about healthy eating includes a picture of a food plate divided into sections: fruits, vegetables, grains, protein, and dairy. This image helps the reader —
choices: See how much of each food group to eat
Know what to buy at the store
questions.correct: See how much of each food group to eat
questions.hint: The plate shows sections of different sizes — what does that tell you?

questions.prompt: Which type of image would BEST help explain how a bicycle works?
choices: A labeled diagram showing bicycle parts
A painting of a bicycle race
questions.correct: A labeled diagram showing bicycle parts
questions.hint: To explain HOW something works, you need to see the parts and what they do.

standards.standard_description: Explain how specific images contribute to and clarify a text.

standards.parent_tip: Ask your child 'What reasons does the author give?' after reading a persuasive or explanatory text.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Recess is important for kids. It gives them time to exercise. It also helps them focus better in class."

What reason does the author give for why recess helps in class?
questions.hint: Read the last sentence — what does recess help kids do in class?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Everyone should drink more water. Water keeps your body healthy. It helps your brain work better. It also gives you energy."

How many reasons does the author give for drinking water?
questions.hint: Count each benefit: healthy body, better brain, and energy. That's three!

questions.prompt:
Read: "Helmets should be worn when riding a bike. They protect your head if you fall. Studies show helmets reduce head injuries by 85%."

What supports the author's point that helmets are important?
questions.hint: The author uses a fact with a number to support the point. Which sentence has the number?

questions.prompt: When an author writes 'because' in a sentence, what usually follows?
choices: A reason that supports their point
questions.correct: A reason that supports their point
questions.hint: 'Because' is a signal word that introduces WHY something is true.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Schools should have gardens. Gardens teach kids about science. They also help kids eat healthier because kids are more likely to eat vegetables they grew themselves."

Which reason explains HOW gardens help kids eat healthier?
choices: Kids eat vegetables they grew themselves
questions.correct: Kids eat vegetables they grew themselves
questions.hint: Look for the sentence with 'because' — that gives the detailed reason.

standards.standard_description: Describe how reasons support specific points the author makes in a text.

standards.parent_tip: Read two short articles about the same topic and help your child find what each one focuses on differently.

questions.prompt: Text A says dogs are great pets because they are loyal. Text B says dogs are great pets because they can be trained. What do BOTH texts agree on?
questions.hint: What main point do both texts share?

questions.prompt: Text A about the ocean focuses on ocean animals. Text B about the ocean focuses on pollution in the ocean. How are these texts different?
choices: They focus on different aspects of the same topic
questions.correct: They focus on different aspects of the same topic
questions.hint: Both texts are about the ocean, but each focuses on something different.

questions.prompt:
Text A: "Bats use sound to find food in the dark." Text B: "Bats eat insects and help farmers by keeping pests away."

What does Text B tell you that Text A does not?
questions.hint: Read Text B — what information is new and not in Text A?

questions.prompt: When comparing two texts on the same topic, what should you look for?
choices: What information is the same and what is different
questions.correct: What information is the same and what is different
questions.hint: Comparing means finding things that are alike AND different.

questions.prompt:
Text A says: "Exercise keeps your heart healthy." Text B says: "Exercise helps you sleep better and makes your bones strong."

Which benefit is mentioned in Text A but NOT Text B?
questions.hint: Read Text A carefully — which benefit does it mention that Text B doesn't?

standards.standard_description: Compare and contrast the most important points presented by two texts on the same topic.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage your child to read nonfiction about topics they enjoy to build reading stamina.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Octopuses are amazing creatures. They have eight arms and three hearts. They can change color to blend in with their surroundings. Some octopuses can even open jars!"

According to the text, how many hearts does an octopus have?
questions.hint: The second sentence lists two number facts. Which one is about hearts?

questions.prompt:
Read: "The Great Wall of China was built over many centuries to protect China from invaders. It stretches over 13,000 miles, making it the longest structure ever built by humans."

Why was the Great Wall built?
questions.hint: The first sentence explains the purpose — to protect from what?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Recycling one aluminum can saves enough energy to power a TV for three hours. Americans throw away enough cans each year to build more than 20 Eiffel Towers."

What is the author trying to show with these facts?
choices: Recycling cans saves a lot of energy
The Eiffel Tower is made of cans
questions.correct: Recycling cans saves a lot of energy
questions.hint: The author compares cans to TV power and Eiffel Towers. Why? To show recycling matters!

questions.prompt:
Read: "Polar bears have black skin under their white fur. The white fur helps them hide in the snow. Their large paws work like snowshoes, helping them walk on ice."

What helps polar bears walk on ice?
questions.hint: Read the last sentence — what works like snowshoes?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Volcanoes form when hot melted rock called magma pushes up through the Earth's surface. When magma comes out, it's called lava. Over time, the lava cools and builds up to form the volcano's cone shape."

What is magma called after it comes out of the volcano?
questions.hint: The second sentence tells you the new name for magma once it's outside.

standards.standard_description: By end of year, read and comprehend informational texts in the grades 2-3 text complexity band proficiently.

standards.parent_tip: Practice sounding out new words together — break them into smaller parts.

questions.prompt: Which word has a long vowel sound?
questions.hint: A long vowel says its own name. Which word has the 'ay' sound?

questions.prompt: What is the root word in 'playing'?
questions.hint: Remove the ending '-ing' — what word is left?

questions.prompt: Which word has the prefix 'un-'?
questions.hint: A prefix is added to the BEGINNING of a base word. 'Un-' + 'happy' = ?

questions.prompt: How many syllables are in the word 'pumpkin'?
questions.hint: Clap it out: pump-kin. How many claps?

questions.prompt: Which word is spelled correctly?
questions.hint: This is a tricky word! Sound it out: be-cause.

standards.standard_description: Know and apply grade-level phonics and word analysis skills in decoding words.

standards.parent_tip: Practice identifying short vowels (like 'a' in 'cat') vs long vowels (like 'a' in 'cake').

questions.prompt: Which word has a SHORT 'a' sound?
questions.hint: Short 'a' sounds like the 'a' in 'cat.' Which word has that sound?

questions.prompt: Which word has a LONG 'o' sound?
questions.hint: Long 'o' says its own name, like 'oh.' Which word sounds like that?

questions.prompt: The word 'bed' has a —
questions.hint: Say 'bed' out loud. Does the 'e' say its name or make a short sound?

questions.prompt: Which pair shows a short vowel word and its long vowel partner?
questions.hint: Adding a silent 'e' at the end makes the vowel long!

questions.prompt: Which word does NOT have a long vowel sound?
questions.hint: Say each word. Three have vowels that say their own name. One has a short 'i.'

standards.standard_description: Distinguish long and short vowels when reading regularly spelled one-syllable words.

standards.parent_tip: Practice vowel teams like 'oa' in boat, 'ee' in tree, and 'ai' in rain.

questions.prompt: In the word 'boat,' what sound does the vowel team 'oa' make?
questions.hint: Say 'boat' — the 'oa' makes the 'oh' sound!

questions.prompt: Which word has the 'ee' vowel team?
questions.hint: Look for two e's side by side!

questions.prompt: The vowel team 'ai' in 'rain' makes the same sound as 'ay' in —
questions.hint: Say 'rain' and 'play' — do the vowels sound the same?

questions.prompt: Which word has the same vowel sound as 'seat'?
questions.hint: The 'ea' in seat makes a long 'e' sound. Which other word has that?

questions.prompt: Which vowel team is in the word 'loud'?
questions.hint: Look at the middle of 'loud' — which two vowels are together?

standards.standard_description: Know spelling-sound correspondences for additional common vowel teams.

standards.parent_tip: Help your child break two-syllable words into parts and sound out each part.

questions.prompt: Break the word 'cupcake' into two syllables:
questions.hint: This is a compound word made of two smaller words!

questions.prompt: The word 'robot' has two syllables. How do you break it apart?
questions.hint: Each syllable needs a vowel. Where's the natural break?

questions.prompt: Which two-syllable word has a long 'i' sound?
questions.hint: Say each word. Which one has the 'eye' sound in it?

questions.prompt: How many syllables are in the word 'music'?
questions.hint: Clap it: mu-sic. How many claps?

questions.prompt: Break 'open' into syllables:
questions.hint: The 'o' is long and open — it gets its own syllable!

standards.standard_description: Decode regularly spelled two-syllable words with long vowels.

standards.parent_tip: Teach your child that 'un-' means 'not' and '-ful' means 'full of' to help decode new words.

questions.prompt: What does 'unkind' mean?
questions.hint: The prefix 'un-' means 'not.' So un + kind = ?

questions.prompt: The suffix '-ful' in 'hopeful' means —
questions.hint: Hope + ful = full of hope!

questions.prompt: What does 'reread' mean?
questions.hint: The prefix 're-' means 'again.' So re + read = ?

questions.prompt: Which word has a suffix?
questions.hint: A suffix goes at the END of a word. '-ly' is a common suffix.

questions.prompt: If 'care' means to look after something, what does 'careless' mean?
questions.hint: The suffix '-less' means 'without.' Without care = ?

standards.standard_description: Decode words with common prefixes and suffixes.

standards.parent_tip: Some words don't follow the rules — help your child learn tricky words like 'said' and 'have' by sight.

questions.prompt: Which word does NOT follow regular phonics rules?
questions.hint: Try sounding it out — does 'said' sound like it's spelled?

questions.prompt: The word 'have' is tricky because —
choices: The 'a' doesn't make the expected sound
It ends with 'e' but the 'a' is short
questions.correct: It ends with 'e' but the 'a' is short
questions.hint: Usually a word ending in 'e' has a long vowel. But 'have' has a short 'a'!

questions.prompt: Which word has a silent letter?
questions.hint: Say each word. In one of them, a letter is there but you don't hear it.

questions.prompt: In the word 'love,' the 'o' makes the sound of —
questions.hint: Say 'love' and 'cup.' The vowel sounds the same!

questions.prompt: Which of these words is a tricky sight word that doesn't follow phonics rules?
questions.hint: Try to sound out each word with regular rules. Which one doesn't work?

standards.standard_description: Identify words with inconsistent but common spelling-sound correspondences.

standards.parent_tip: Practice sight words like 'people,' 'again,' and 'friend' — these need to be memorized, not sounded out.

questions.prompt: Which word is spelled correctly?
questions.hint: 'People' is a tricky word — the 'eo' doesn't sound like you'd expect.

questions.prompt: Choose the correct spelling:
questions.hint: Remember: 'i' before 'e' in friend!

questions.prompt: Which sentence uses 'their' correctly?
questions.hint: 'Their' means 'belonging to them.' Which sentence shows something belonging to them?

questions.prompt: Choose the correct spelling of the word that means 'one more time':
questions.hint: This tricky word ends with '-ain' like 'rain.'

questions.prompt: Which word is an irregularly spelled word you need to memorize?
questions.hint: Three of these words can be sounded out. One is tricky and needs to be memorized.

standards.standard_description: Recognize and read grade-appropriate irregularly spelled words.

standards.parent_tip: Listen to your child read aloud — encourage them to read smoothly and with expression.

questions.prompt: What does it mean to read fluently?
questions.hint: Fluent reading sounds natural, like talking — not too fast, not too slow.

questions.prompt: When you see an exclamation mark (!) at the end of a sentence, you should read it with —
questions.hint: An exclamation mark means the sentence has strong emotion!

questions.prompt: If you don't understand a sentence after reading it, what should you do?
choices: Ask someone to read the whole book
questions.hint: Good readers go back and reread to make sure they understand.

questions.prompt:
Read: "'Stop!' yelled the crossing guard."

How should you read the word 'Stop'?
questions.hint: The crossing guard 'yelled' — so you should read it like a yell!

questions.prompt: When a good reader comes to a word they don't know, they —
choices: Use clues from the sentence to figure it out
questions.correct: Use clues from the sentence to figure it out
questions.hint: The other words in the sentence can help you figure out the mystery word!

standards.standard_description: Read with sufficient accuracy and fluency to support comprehension.

standards.parent_tip: Before reading, set a purpose: 'Let's read to find out how butterflies are born.'

questions.prompt:
Read: "The farmer planted seeds in the spring. He watered them every day. By summer, his garden was full of tomatoes, peppers, and corn."

What grew in the farmer's garden?
questions.hint: Read the last sentence — it lists what grew!

questions.prompt: Before you start reading, it helps to ask yourself —
choices: What do I want to learn from this?
questions.correct: What do I want to learn from this?
questions.hint: Setting a purpose helps you focus while reading.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Dolphins are mammals, not fish. They breathe air and feed milk to their babies. Dolphins are very smart and can learn tricks."

What makes dolphins different from fish?
choices: They breathe air and feed milk to babies
questions.correct: They breathe air and feed milk to babies
questions.hint: The passage says dolphins are mammals, not fish. What makes them mammals?

questions.prompt:
Read: "Ben's favorite book is about space. He reads it every week because he wants to be an astronaut someday."

Why does Ben read the space book so often?
choices: It's the only book he has
He wants to be an astronaut
questions.correct: He wants to be an astronaut
questions.hint: The sentence after 'because' tells you the reason.

questions.prompt:
Read: "Earthworms help gardens by making tunnels in the soil. The tunnels let air and water reach plant roots."

How do earthworm tunnels help plants?
choices: They make the garden look nice
They let air and water reach the roots
questions.correct: They let air and water reach the roots
questions.hint: Read the second sentence — what do the tunnels let through?

standards.standard_description: Read grade-level text with purpose and understanding.

standards.parent_tip: Model reading aloud with expression — change your voice for different characters and show excitement!

questions.prompt: How should you read this sentence? "I can't believe we won the game!"
questions.hint: The exclamation mark and 'I can't believe' show strong, happy feelings!

questions.prompt: When you read a question aloud, your voice should —
questions.hint: Try saying 'Are you coming?' — notice how your voice rises at the end?

questions.prompt: A character in a story whispers, 'Shhh, the baby is sleeping.' How should you read this line?
questions.hint: The character is whispering — match that with your voice!

questions.prompt: What does reading at an 'appropriate rate' mean?
choices: Reading so slowly that it's hard to follow
Reading at a comfortable speed — not too fast, not too slow
questions.correct: Reading at a comfortable speed — not too fast, not too slow
questions.hint: Think about how you talk — that's a good speed for reading aloud too.

questions.prompt: How should you read this line from a character who is scared? "W-what was that noise?"
questions.hint: The dashes in 'W-what' show stuttering — the character is scared!

standards.standard_description: Read grade-level text orally with accuracy, appropriate rate, and expression.

standards.parent_tip: When your child reads a word wrong and the sentence doesn't make sense, encourage them to try again.

questions.prompt: You read: 'The dog buried a bone in the yard.' But you accidentally read 'bone' as 'bun.' What should you do?
choices: Go back and reread because 'bun' doesn't make sense
Ask someone to read for you
questions.correct: Go back and reread because 'bun' doesn't make sense
questions.hint: Does 'The dog buried a bun in the yard' make sense? If not, try again!

questions.prompt: Read: 'The bird flew to its ____.' Which word fits best?
questions.hint: Where do birds live? Use the rest of the sentence to decide.

questions.prompt: What is a good strategy when a sentence doesn't make sense?
choices: Reread the sentence and try the hard word again
questions.correct: Reread the sentence and try the hard word again
questions.hint: Good readers slow down and try again when something doesn't sound right.

questions.prompt: Read: 'The cat climbed up the tall ___.' Which word makes the most sense?
questions.hint: What tall thing can a cat climb?

questions.prompt: You read a word as 'horse' but the sentence says: 'The family lives in a big _____ on the hill.' What should the word probably be?
questions.hint: A family lives in a ____. Which word makes sense?

standards.standard_description: Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as necessary.

standards.parent_tip: When your child encounters an unknown word, help them use the sentence around it as a clue.

questions.prompt:
Read: 'The tiny kitten was so small it fit in my hand.'

What does 'tiny' mean?
questions.hint: The sentence says the kitten was so small it fit in a hand. 'Tiny' means the same as 'small.'

questions.prompt:
The word 'bat' can mean a flying animal OR a stick used in baseball. In this sentence, what does 'bat' mean?

'Jake swung the bat and hit the ball.'
choices: A stick for hitting a ball
questions.correct: A stick for hitting a ball
questions.hint: Jake swung it and hit a ball — that's baseball!

questions.prompt:
Read: 'The exhausted runner sat down after the race.'

What does 'exhausted' most likely mean?
questions.hint: After a race, how would a runner feel? The sentence gives you context.

questions.prompt:
What does 'ring' mean in this sentence?

'Did you hear the phone ring?'
questions.hint: You can 'hear' a ring — so it must be a sound!

questions.prompt:
Read: 'The bright sun made everything glow.'

What does 'bright' mean here?
choices: Shining with a lot of light
questions.correct: Shining with a lot of light
questions.hint: The sun is shining — 'bright' describes how much light it gives off.

standards.standard_description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases.

standards.parent_tip: Teach your child to look at the words AROUND a tricky word for clues about what it means.

questions.prompt:
Read: 'The enormous elephant was the biggest animal at the zoo.'

The word 'enormous' means —
questions.hint: The sentence says it was the BIGGEST animal. What word means very big?

questions.prompt:
Read: 'The children were famished after playing all day, so they ate a huge dinner.'

What does 'famished' mean?
questions.hint: They ate a huge dinner after playing all day. How did they feel before eating?

questions.prompt:
Read: 'Be cautious when crossing the street — look both ways first.'

What does 'cautious' mean?
questions.hint: Looking both ways before crossing is something you do to be safe and careful.

questions.prompt:
Read: 'The frigid wind made everyone shiver and bundle up in their coats.'

The word 'frigid' means —
questions.hint: People shivered and bundled up. What kind of wind would make you do that?

questions.prompt:
Read: 'Mom said the movie was hilarious — she couldn't stop laughing!'

What does 'hilarious' mean?
questions.hint: She couldn't stop LAUGHING. What word describes something that makes you laugh?

standards.standard_description: Use sentence-level context as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

standards.parent_tip: Practice prefix meanings: 'un-' = not, 're-' = again, 'pre-' = before.

questions.prompt: If 'happy' means feeling good, what does 'unhappy' mean?
questions.hint: The prefix 'un-' means 'not.'

questions.prompt: What does 'retell' mean?
questions.hint: The prefix 're-' means 'again.' Re + tell = ?

questions.prompt: The word 'preview' means —
questions.hint: 'Pre-' means 'before.' Pre + view = view before!

questions.prompt: If 'lock' means to close with a key, what does 'unlock' mean?
questions.hint: 'Un-' means 'not' or 'the opposite.' The opposite of locking is...?

questions.prompt: What does 'disagree' mean?
questions.hint: The prefix 'dis-' means 'not' or 'opposite of.'

standards.standard_description: Determine the meaning of the new word formed when a known prefix is added to a known word.

standards.parent_tip: Show your child how knowing 'play' helps them understand 'player,' 'playful,' and 'replay.'

questions.prompt: If 'teach' means to help someone learn, what does a 'teacher' do?
questions.hint: The root word is 'teach.' A teacher is a person who teaches!

questions.prompt: You know that 'paint' means to put color on something. What does 'painter' mean?
questions.hint: The '-er' ending often means 'a person who does something.'

questions.prompt: The root word 'help' is in all of these words EXCEPT —
questions.hint: Look at each word — which one does NOT have 'help' in it?

questions.prompt: If 'joy' means happiness, what does 'joyful' mean?
questions.hint: The root is 'joy' and the suffix '-ful' means 'full of.'

questions.prompt: You know 'move' means to go from one place to another. What does 'movement' mean?
questions.hint: The root word 'move' plus '-ment' means 'the act of' something.

standards.standard_description: Use a known root word as a clue to the meaning of an unknown word with the same root.

standards.parent_tip: Play compound word games: 'What two words make up sunflower? sun + flower!'

questions.prompt: What does 'sunflower' mean?
choices: A flower that blocks the sun
A flower that faces the sun
questions.correct: A flower that faces the sun
questions.hint: Break it apart: sun + flower. It's a flower connected to the sun!

questions.prompt: The word 'raincoat' is made up of which two words?
questions.hint: A coat you wear when it rains!

questions.prompt: What is a 'bookshelf'?
questions.hint: Book + shelf. Where do you put books?

questions.prompt: If 'light' means something that shines and 'house' means a building, what is a 'lighthouse'?
choices: A building with a bright light to guide ships
questions.correct: A building with a bright light to guide ships
questions.hint: Think about a building (house) with a big shining light. Where would you find this?

questions.prompt: Which word is a compound word?
questions.hint: A compound word is made of two smaller words put together. Which word can be split?

standards.standard_description: Use knowledge of the meaning of individual words to predict the meaning of compound words.

standards.parent_tip: Show your child how to look up words in a dictionary or glossary — practice finding words alphabetically.

questions.prompt: Where would you find the meaning of a word in a nonfiction book?
questions.hint: A glossary is a mini-dictionary in the back of a book!

questions.prompt: Words in a dictionary are organized —
questions.hint: To find a word, you need to know the ABC order!

questions.prompt: Which word would come FIRST in a dictionary?
questions.hint: Which letter comes first in the alphabet: a, b, c, or d?

questions.prompt: A glossary is different from a dictionary because —
choices: It only includes words used in that specific book
It's at the front of the book
questions.correct: It only includes words used in that specific book
questions.hint: A dictionary has ALL words. A glossary has only the words from one book.

questions.prompt: You want to look up 'penguin' in the dictionary. Which guide words tell you it's on that page?
questions.hint: Guide words show the first and last words on a page. 'Penguin' falls between which pair?

standards.standard_description: Use glossaries and beginning dictionaries to determine or clarify the meaning of words.

standards.parent_tip: Play word games — find synonyms, antonyms, and connect words to real-life experiences.

questions.prompt: Which word means almost the same as 'big'?
questions.hint: A synonym is a word with a similar meaning. Which word is similar to 'big'?

questions.prompt: Which word is the OPPOSITE of 'hot'?
questions.hint: The opposite of something very warm would be something very...?

questions.prompt: Which group of words are all related to 'weather'?
questions.hint: Which group has words you'd hear in a weather report?

questions.prompt: When would you use the word 'whisper'?
choices: In a library when you need to be quiet
questions.correct: In a library when you need to be quiet
questions.hint: Whispering means talking very softly. Where would you need to be quiet?

questions.prompt: Which word means the same as 'glad'?
questions.hint: 'I'm so glad you're here!' — does that sound happy or sad?

standards.standard_description: Demonstrate understanding of word relationships and nuances in word meanings.

standards.parent_tip: Connect vocabulary to daily life: 'That soup is steaming — what does steaming mean?'

questions.prompt: Which of these foods could be described as 'crunchy'?
questions.hint: Think about which food makes a cracking sound when you bite it.

questions.prompt: Which action is 'courageous'?
questions.hint: 'Courageous' means brave. Which action takes bravery?

questions.prompt: When might you feel 'frustrated'?
choices: When you open a birthday present
When you can't solve a puzzle after many tries
When you eat your favorite food
When you play with your best friend
questions.correct: When you can't solve a puzzle after many tries
questions.hint: Frustrated means feeling stuck or annoyed because something is hard.

questions.prompt: Which place would you describe as 'peaceful'?
choices: A quiet garden with birds singing
questions.correct: A quiet garden with birds singing
questions.hint: 'Peaceful' means calm and quiet. Which place sounds calm?

questions.prompt: Which animal would you describe as 'swift'?
questions.hint: 'Swift' means very fast. Which animal is the fastest?

standards.standard_description: Identify real-life connections between words and their use.

standards.parent_tip: Discuss word differences: 'Is it the same to toss, throw, and hurl? How are they different?'

questions.prompt: Put these words in order from LEAST strong to MOST strong: toss, hurl, throw
questions.hint: Tossing is gentle, throwing is normal, hurling is very powerful!

questions.prompt: Which word means being MORE than just 'warm'?
questions.hint: If warm goes up in temperature, what's the stronger word?

questions.prompt: Which word shows a BIGGER size than 'big'?
questions.hint: Big is large. What word means REALLY, REALLY big?

questions.prompt: Put these words in order from quietest to loudest: yell, whisper, talk
questions.hint: Start with the softest voice and end with the loudest.

questions.prompt: Which word means walking SLOWLY and tiredly?
questions.hint: Sprinting is fast, marching is steady, skipping is bouncy. Which one is slow and tired?

standards.standard_description: Distinguish shades of meaning among closely related verbs and adjectives.

standards.parent_tip: Encourage your child to use descriptive words — 'Don't just say nice, say wonderful, kind, or thoughtful!'

questions.prompt: Which sentence uses an adjective to describe the dog?
questions.hint: An adjective describes a noun. Which sentence tells you what KIND of dog?

questions.prompt:
Which word is an adverb in this sentence?

'The girl sang beautifully.'
questions.hint: An adverb describes HOW something is done. How did she sing?

questions.prompt:
Fill in the blank with the best adjective:

'The ____ storm knocked down trees.'
questions.hint: You need a word that describes the storm (a noun). Which word tells you what kind of storm?

questions.prompt: Which sentence uses an adverb?
choices: He ran quickly to the bus.
questions.correct: He ran quickly to the bus.
questions.hint: An adverb tells HOW, WHEN, or WHERE. Which sentence has a word that tells HOW?

questions.prompt: Choose the MOST descriptive sentence:
choices: I hungrily ate a warm, cheesy sandwich.
questions.correct: I hungrily ate a warm, cheesy sandwich.
questions.hint: The most descriptive sentence uses adjectives and adverbs to paint a picture!

standards.standard_description: Use words and phrases acquired through conversations, reading, and being read to, including adjectives and adverbs.
